seed: I feel lonely even when I'm around people, and then I get annoyed at myself for feeling that way.

transcript.content: I feel lonely even when I'm around people, and then I get annoyed at myself for feeling that way.

It sounds like there’s a disconnect between being surrounded by people and actually feeling connected.  What do you think might be contributing to that feeling of loneliness despite being in social situations?

Yeah, it does feel like that sometimes. I can be in a crowd, laughing, and then suddenly it just hits me—I feel so alone. I think part of it is that I struggle to really open up to people. I don’t know, maybe I worry they won’t understand me. It's like I'm just going through the motions, but I don't feel like I really belong anywhere. It
When you say "going through the motions," does that mean there are parts of your life where you feel disconnected from what's happening?

I guess it feels like I’m just acting most of the time. I can be in a group, and I’ll laugh or smile, but inside, I feel this emptiness. It’s tough because I want to connect, but I keep holding back. Sometimes I think if I show who I really am, people won’t get it or they’ll judge me. So I end up feeling even
It sounds like there's a gap between how you appear and how you feel when you're around others. What makes you think that showing your true self would lead to people not understanding or judging you?

Yeah, it really does feel like a gap. I think I've just had experiences in the past where when I opened up, it didn't go well. People didn’t react how I hoped, and it made me feel even more isolated. I guess those memories stick with you, you know? So now I’m kind of stuck in this pattern, holding back in case I get hurt again.
It sounds like the way things went in the past have really shaped how you approach new situations.  What makes you think that opening up might lead to a similar outcome this time?

I suppose it’s just that, well, I've had those moments where it didn’t end well, and they felt really intense and painful. It’s hard to shake that feeling. I know not everyone is the same, but it’s like this nagging voice in my head that keeps reminding me of the times I was let down. I guess it makes me second-guess myself and just stay quiet
It sounds like these past experiences have a powerful hold on you, even when things are going well.  What kind of impact does that "nagging voice" have on your decisions in those situations?

Yeah, that voice definitely keeps me on edge. It makes it hard to trust myself in social situations. Like, I'll hesitate to speak up or share anything personal, even when I really want to. Sometimes I’ll even just avoid situations altogether because I’m scared of how it might go. I don’t want to feel that disappointment again, so I end up just... holding back.
It sounds like the possibility of a negative outcome is influencing your choices in social settings. What kind of evidence do you have that suggests those outcomes are inevitable?

I mean, I’ve had a few experiences that really stuck with me. Like that time I opened up to a friend about how I was feeling, and they just kind of brushed it off. It felt really invalidating, and it’s hard to forget that. So, when I think about trying again, that memory comes back and makes me hesitate. It’s like I can’t shake the fear

It sounds like this past experience has created a strong association between sharing your feelings and feeling dismissed.  What do you think might happen if you tried opening up to someone who seemed genuinely interested in hearing what you had to say?

I guess there’s a part of me that really wants to believe it could be different this time. But then there's this other part that worries it might just end up being the same. I imagine feeling vulnerable and then just getting brushed off again, and that terrifies me. I wish I could just go for it without that fear hanging over me, you know? It's frustrating to feel stuck like this

It sounds like there’s a real tension between wanting something new and the worry that things might stay the same. What makes you think that feeling vulnerable would necessarily lead to being brushed off again?

I want to believe it could be different this time, but I can’t shake the worry that it might just end up the same. I imagine being vulnerable and getting brushed off again, and it terrifies me. Sometimes I just want to go for it, but that fear hangs over me and makes me feel stuck. It’s frustrating, feeling like I can’t break free from that pattern.
It sounds like you're caught between a desire for something new and the weight of past experiences. What evidence do you have that suggests this time might truly be different?

It’s true, I do feel torn. I mean, part of me hopes that maybe people have changed or that I’ve changed a bit too. But then, I can’t help but remember all those times it didn’t go how I wanted. It’s hard to see any real evidence that it might be different now. I guess I just keep thinking about what’s gone wrong before instead of looking

When we focus on past experiences that didn't go as planned, it can make it difficult to imagine things being different now. What makes you think those past experiences are the best guide for what might happen in the future?

I feel really torn about it. On one hand, I hope maybe things could be different now. But the memories of past experiences keep creeping in, making me doubt. I can’t shake the feeling that I’ll just end up disappointed again. It’s frustrating when I want to have hope, but I keep getting pulled back to what’s gone wrong before.
